abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Services Support Project
            (SSP) for Comoros were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory; risk to development outcome was substantial;
            Bank performance was satisfactory; Borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: the
            project confirms the effectiveness of non-traditional
            structures to deliver social services in countries with weak
            governmental capacity. A project implementation unit, such
            as the Fonds d'Appui au Developpement Communautaire
            (FADC), can successfully deliver social services to
            populations that will otherwise be left underserved by
            traditional state structures. Financing mechanisms and
            intensive community training for the maintenance of
            community-driven infrastructure development need to be
            included in sub-project design. The cash-for-work activities
            introduced under the SSP could provide a framework through
            which to begin a broader dialogue on social protection with
            the Government. The FADC is perceived among some
            stakeholders as primarily an organization that constructs
            social infrastructures. In low capacity contexts where
            funding resources are limited, development programming could
            leverage synergies between donors and implementing agencies.
            Comoros provides a relatively successful case of donor
            coordination, with different organizations acting as lead
            agencies across the social sectors; however, exploiting
            synergies between projects would help amplify their impacts.
            Projects in low capacity contexts require intensive
            supervision. The FADC made steady progress toward the SSP
            Project Development Objectives (PDOs) throughout Project
            implementation; however, serious mismanagement challenges
            arose that required intensive World Bank supervision.
